captions.text:
For as far back
as we can trace our existence,

humans have been fascinated 
with death and resurrection.

Nearly every religion in the world 
has some interpretation of them,
and from our earliest myths

to the latest cinematic blockbusters,
the dead keep coming back.
But is resurrection really possible?

And what is the actual difference between 
a living creature and a dead body, anyway?

To understand what death is, 
we need to understand what life is.

One ancient theory 
was an idea called vitalism,

which claimed 
that living things were unique

because they were filled 
with a special substance, or energy,
that was the essence of life.
Whether it was called qi,
lifeblood,
or humors,

the belief in such an essence 
was common throughout the world,

and still persists 
in the stories of creatures
who can somehow drain life from others,

or some form of magical sources 
that can replenish it.

Vitalism began to fade 
in the Western world

following the Scientific Revolution 
in the 17th century.
René Descartes advanced the notion

that the human body was essentially 
no different from any other machine,

brought to life by a divinely created soul
located in the brain's pineal gland.

And in 1907, Dr. Duncan McDougall 
even claimed that the soul had mass,

weighing patients immediately
before and after death in an attempt to prove it.

Though his experiments were discredited,
much like the rest of vitalism,

traces of his theory 
still come up in popular culture.

But where do all these discredited 
theories leave us?

What we now know is 
that life is not contained
in some magical substance or spark,

but within the ongoing 
biological processes themselves.
And to understand these processes,

we need to zoom down 
to the level of our individual cells.
Inside each of these cells,

chemical reactions 
are constantly occurring,

powered by the glucose and oxygen
that our bodies convert

into the energy-carrying molecule
known as ATP.

Cells use this energy
for everything from repair
to growth
to reproduction.

Not only does it take a lot of energy 
to make the necessary molecules,

but it takes even more 
to get them where they need to be.
The universal phenomenon of entropy

means that molecules will tend 
towards diffusing randomly,

moving from areas 
of high concentration to low concentration,

or even breaking apart 
into smaller molecules and atoms.

So cells must constantly keep 
entropy in check

by using energy to maintain 
their molecules
in the very complicated formations

necessary for biological functions
to occur.

The breaking down of these arrangements 
when the entire cell succumbs to entropy
is what eventually results in death.

This is the reason organisms 
can't be simply sparked back to life
once they've already died.
We can pump air into someone's lungs,
but it won't do much good

if the many other processes
involved in the respiratory cycle
are no longer functioning.

Similarly, the electric shock
from a defibrillator
doesn't jump-start an inanimate heart,

but resynchronizes the muscle cells 
in an abnormally beating heart
so they regain their normal rhythm.

This can prevent a person from dying, 
but it won't raise a dead body,

or a monster sewn together 
from dead bodies.

So it would seem 
that all our various medical miracles

can delay or prevent death
but not reverse it.
But that's not as simple as it sounds

because constant advancements 
in technology and medicine
have resulted in diagnoses such as coma,

describing potentially 
reversible conditions,

under which people would have previously 
been considered dead.

In the future, the point of no return 
may be pushed even further.

Some animals are known 
to extend their lifespans
or survive extreme conditions
by slowing down their biological processes

to the point where 
they are virtually paused.

And research into cryonics 
hopes to achieve the same

by freezing dying people 
and reviving them later

when newer technology 
is able to help them.

See, if the cells are frozen, 
there's very little molecular movement,
and diffusion practically stops.

Even if all of a person's cellular 
processes had already broken down,

this could still conceivably be reversed 
by a swarm of nanobots,

moving all the molecules 
back to their proper positions,

and injecting all of the cells 
with ATP at the same time,

presumably causing the body 
to simply pick up where it left off.

So if we think of life 
not as some magical spark,

but a state of incredibly complex,
self-perpetuating organization,

death is just 
the process of increasing entropy
that destroys this fragile balance.

And the point at which 
someone is completely dead
turns out not to be a fixed constant,

but simply a matter 
of how much of this entropy
we're currently capable of reversing.

title: At what moment are you dead? - Randall Hayes

In addition aristocrats, the one percent, would live on and on and on and 
reserve all their money for themselves. Wouldn't that just built up their

comments.author: Chris Paine

comments.text: On death (and cellular entropy).﻿
comments.author: Jared Morgan (jaredmorgs)

comments.text:
Cryogenically freezing people won't be able to work in the foreseeable 
future. The process of freezing someone causes all the water in their body 
to freeze, including the water in their cells. When water freezes, it 
expands. This means that freezing someone in order to preserve their body 
for later reanimation would irreparably burst many of the biological 
membranes in their body, conceivably beyond repair

Not saying that it's impossible, but the techniques of freezing and 
reanimation will have a long way to come before being able to freeze 
someone in a state where they can be revived.﻿

where you're half-frozen, which would kill the half that's not frozen.

comments.author: ALBERT EINSTEIN

comments.text:
+Johann S The way you define supernatural is different, you phrase it as 
something we haven't been understood yet, something that might be 
supernatural today, but scientific data tomorrow. 
However, supernatural, magical, mysterious, are more than commonly used to 
describe things that have no explanation, just are. Things or events that 
happen without the restriction of natural laws, and can never be fully 
explained.
This is the definition I'm trying to mark off as unusable, useless, and 
something that we should avoid altogether since it has happened before, and 
it will happen again, that people take action upon non-evidenced beliefs, 
that frequently lead to disastrous results, labeling their belief as 
"supernatural" or "magical" or "mysterious" and that it doesn't need to be 
explained.
comments.author: TheDrB0B

comments.text:
I left out more than just the word supernatural. After all I wasn't going 
re-post the multiple definitions again.
But I was trying to go more towards the second definition, which I thought 
was the most common definition today, but perhaps this is only the case 
nearby where I live. That definition was the "wonderful; exciting" 
definition as well usually "mysterious" tagged along with it

But if a person feels like using a word like supernatural (going by that 
common definition) then I don't see why they can't. Example, we people have 
said things in the past (including very recent past) of things can't do 
this, or no way this specific part of the organ does that as well. Yet 
later with more information / research those people or person start to find 
out more
After all, the science of everything doesn't change, it is our knowledge or 
understanding that does.
comments.author: Johann S

comments.text:
+Johann S Not really, magic by definition is something out of the natural 
laws, hence "supernatural" (I did noticed how you conveniently left out 
that word).
You are right though, if you want to call the unknown "magic" you're in 
your right to do so. But the common definition of magic doesn't allow the 
understanding of such magic, it just is and is unquestionable.
comments.author: TheDrB0B

comments.text:
+TheDrB0B I don't really get your point though. 
So far we haven't explained everything yet. And that "mystery" and 
"excitement" is what brings many people to lean more, as well as try to 
figure out more That is a scientific process, which is why the word 
"magical" can be used.
comments.author: Johann S

comments.text:
+Johann S The keywords being "mysterious" and "supernatural", which in 
turn, mean something that we haven't or can't explain.
If you remember, the scientific process is nothing but trying to explain 
and use the world around us.
And yes, I dare you to find a common definition of magic which doesn't 
involve things that happen without an explanation.
comments.author: TheDrB0B

comments.text:
+TheDrB0B Magic - *noun* 1) the power of apparently influencing the course 
of events by using mysterious or supernatural forces.*adjective* 
2) wonderful; exciting
*verb*3) move, change, or create by or as if by magic.

How isn't the scientific process of things magical? Especially since many 
things currently are not explained?Or even your brain wrapping around the 
existence of all these things. 


Really in the end it depends on how you define: "Magic" & "Magical" No 
matter which definition you choose, even if it's the many others that were 
not placed here, you're going to have a hard time proving that everything 
isn't or even a 'contrary' to "very magical"

comments.author: Ajay kumar

comments.text:
+Ajay kumar please don't believe everything you read or ear about... There 
are major biological differences between tortoise and humans: 1) tortoise 
are cold blooded 2) tortoise spend 99% of their lifes doing nothing 3) Why 
die old of boredom? 

Aging is caused by the degradation of our DNA, everytime our cells divide 
or our DNA is retranscripted, there are errors, with time the errors become 
too important and these cells kill themselves or get killed by the body. 
Sometimes they become cancerous. At some point we get to our natural limit, 
our biochemistry isn't as performant as it used to and some of our 
biological processes shut down. Aging and dying can't be avoided.

The only thing that will make the difference between someone that die of 
old age at 90 or 120 is DNA and physiological strength in general.
comments.author: hillcon45

comments.text:
Your lifespan is determined by a vast array of factors, including genetics 
and diet. Ultimately, the best way to life a long life to die of 'old age', 
is to avoid dying of anything else e.g. cancer, car accidents or flu. 
Breathing slowly will not stop you from getting cancer or malaria.

therefore our lives would be easier because we wouldn't need to spend all 
our money on food or health. BUT every event is worth 0% if you live until 
infinity, so you're personal life would be worthless, all your events would 
be valueless. Let's say you lived through a golden age that lasted for 2 
million years, now divide that by infinity (even if you mathematically 
can't do so), the result would be 0. It's like the function "1/x" where "1" 
is the event, and "x" is your lifespan. Knowing that one day we will die, 
won't it make us aspire for greatness?

can learn a lot by pondering, just as he did.
comments.author: David Munoz

comments.text:
+David Munoz Jesus had the weight of the world on his shoulders. Even 
before the crucifixion began, he clearly had physical symptoms associated 
with severe stress. The night before the execution, his disciples reported 
seeing Jesus in agony on the Mount of Olives. Not only did he not sleep all 
night, but he seems to have been sweating profusely. So great was the 
stress that tiny blood vessels were rupturing in his sweat glands and 
emitting as great red drops that fell to the ground (see Luke 22:44). This 
symptom of severe stress is called hematohidrosis. Jesus was physically 
exhausted and in danger of going into shock unless he received fluids 
(which he apparently did not). 

Having previously been beaten by the Jews, it was now the Romans’ turn. The 
beatings administered by Roman soldiers are well known to be very bloody, 
leaving lacerations all over the body. Romans designed their whips to cut 
the flesh from their victim’s bodies. These beatings were designed to be 
painful to the extreme. It would also cause a fluid build up around his 
lungs. In addition, a crown of thorns was forced into his scalp which was 
capable of severely irritating major nerves in his head, causing increasing 
and excruciating pain, as the hours wore on.

In Christ’s severely stressed condition, these beatings were easily enough 
to kill him. His body was horribly bruised, cut and bleeding. Having had no 
nourishment for many hours, and having lost fluids through profuse sweating 
and much bleeding, Jesus would have been severely dehydrated. This brutal 
torture would certainly be sending him into what doctors today call a 
"shock", and shock kills.

In addition, Jesus was forced to carry the the wooden beam on which he 
would die. Imagine the effect of carrying a heavy weight if you were in 
that condition.

His median nerve of his hands were pierced by iron nails, his foot's 
plantar nerve ruptured with an iron nail. His body on the cross was 
positioned in a way which makes it difficult for him to breathe. There is 
no question that it was painful beyond words and Jesus chose and willed his 
moment of death. "No one can take my life from me. I sacrifice it 
voluntarily. For I have the authority to lay it down when I want to and 
also to take it up again. For this is what my Father has commanded."

Near the end, a criminal beside him mocked, "If you are the Christ, save 
yourself and us!" Little did this sinner know that the man he was speaking 
to hung there voluntarily. He was speaking to our father, capable of 
releasing all the power in the universe and beyond, and easily saving 
himself. Jesus remained in this agony and shame, not because he was 
powerless, but because of his incredible love for humanity. He suffered to 
provide the needed way of salvation for you and me.

Lastly, you have no idea the punishment the roman soldiers would have to 
endure if the crucifixion did not go as planned. "Crucifixion is a form of 
slow and painful *execution*", the roman soldiers made sure Jesus died on 
that cross by piercing him with a spear, otherwise they themselves would be 
facing great punishments from their empire. John 19:32 "One of the 
soldiers, however, pierced his side with a spear, and immediately blood 
flowed out".

Look up these two terms:
- Flagrum
- Holy Lance

Thanks for your text, really had a fun time replying to it (boredom :p).
comments.author: Misty Turner

comments.text:
Karl Marx was not a blood thirsty regime leader. Do you have any direct 
quotes from Stalin, Mao, Pol Pot, etc.?

If you know which historians claimed that only 6000 people were killed in 
the name of Christianity over 350 years I'd like to check it out.
comments.author: Alan W

comments.text:
+Alan W Communists leaders were motivated by a strong desire to impose an 
ideological "package" over the whole world. And yes this package included 
the eradication of religion. It was defined by arch-atheist, Karl Marx, as 
"The opium of the people." (go read about it) According to Marx, religion 
helped keep the masses passive before the abuse of the wealthy and 
powerful, and the only way to free them from the "stupor," God and religion 
had to be eradicated. Large numbers of religious were persecuted and killed 
for practicing religion, and for being interference to atheist-communist 
expansion.

Few quotes for you to read:

"You know, they are fooling us, there is no God...all this talk about God 
is sheer nonsense" 

"The first requisite for the happiness of the people is the abolition of 
religion"

"Atheism is the natural and inseparable part of Communism."

"Our program necessarily includes the propaganda of atheism."

"We do not fight against believers and not even clergymen. WE FIGHT AGAINST 
GOD to snatch believers from Him."

You can argue that religion caused atrocities all you want, and i agree 
with you. It's true that religion has been implicated in all sorts of 
conflict and violence throughout human history. I'm not saying there isn't 
blood on the hands of the faithful, religion can be a force of great harm. 
But the picture is much more complex than is often implied. For example, 
dinner party guests are likely to nod in agreement when someone mentions 
the "millions killed" at the hands of the church but historians now suggest 
around 5,000 - 6,000 over a 350 year period. That's less than 18 a year! of 
course one a year is terrible enough, but the point that i'm trying to make 
is that reality appears a long way from what you are often served up. 
Likewise the idea that most of the wars of history have been caused by 
religion is demonstrably false.
comments.author: Misty Turner

comments.text:
+Misty Turner Sigh...wrong. None of those regimes used atheism as their 
ideology to commit genocide and human rights violations. As a matter of 
fact they themselves were the religion. They were the cult of personality 
that couldn't be challenged. Give me a single sourced quote from anyone of 
those "leaders" that outright claims that their atheism was their primary 
motivation for their acts.
comments.author: Alan W

comments.text:
+Alan W Well, the same goes to you i'm afraid. State-imposed atheism was a 
defining feature of brutal 20th century regimes led by Stalin, Tito, Mao 
Zedong, and Pol Pot among others, which resulted in the suffering and 
murder of millions. Tens of thousands of Russian Christians alone were 
executed for their beliefs by anti-religious. So it's not just religious 
ideology that causes problems. And you should not forget that we humans 
fight over small bits of compressed carbon, tracts of dirt, addictive 
mind-altering substances and soccer matches etc...

There are flaws on both sides, nobody's perfect.

comments.text:
Everything-and I mean EVERYTHING- will die by entropy. All atoms decay, 
granted it does take a very long time, and all subatomic particles will 
decay. Once they do, they will diffuse into an equilibrium with energy 
equally distributed. Whether or not the idea sounds like shit doesn't mean 
it is. Whether or not an idea is true determines if it is shit. The sun 
does not have infinite energy to stay together, so it will eventually burn 
out and the sun dies, allowing its heat to spread evenly. Say the heat 
doesn't kill the hydra, well now the hydra has no energy source. Without 
any energy, it won't be able to do anything and it will die. Once plants 
and herbivores die, they'll be eaten by omnivores and carnivores. Then the 
decomposers will eat their remains. Eventually all food supply will empty 
out meaning no nutrition or energy for any life on earth, causing them to 
die. The core of the earth will cool down and the earth will no longer be 
protected by its magnetic field. It is now going to be affected by high 
amounts of radiation, causing it to become like mars. The water will 
vaporize and the atmosphere will disappear, dissipating evenly. Eventually, 
all stars will die out and our universe will continue expanding. Any damage 
to the earth will be irreversible unless there is energy to allow it to 
become back to its ordered state. As the earth breaks apart into small 
rocky particles, the atoms in those particles, given enough time, will 
decay down into fundamental particles that will eventually be floating in 
the universe and not interacting with anything. With no energy differences 
or interaction, life is not possible and the universe will "die" in a heat 
death.

Sweet dreams.
comments.author: turtlebomb44

comments.author: ridimwave

comments.text:
1. Animals like hydras die- a lot. They are just as vulnerable to 
starvation, predation, disease, or pH/temperature changes in the water or 
air. 
2. Stars "die" shortly after using up all their helium. Their equivalent of 
"gasoline" in their engine runs out.
3. Planets do not "die" because they do not have energy in the first place. 
Planets are literally giant rocks. The rock itself isn't an 
energy-consuming object in the least.

comments.text:
+TheVintageRomance
"The process has nothing to do with the finished product"
Well I'm not necessarily saying that. I'm saying something along the lines 
of
"The finished product is not part of the process"
Death happens only to the living, but death is not really a "part" of it. 
That would be like saying the silence at the end of a song is part of the 
song. Death is the opposite of living, so it doesn't make sense for it to 
be a part of life. I believe a better phrase would be "The fate of all the 
living is death." Dying is just the inevitable result of life, like how 
shadows are an inevitable result of light, but shadows are not part of 
light.
